utterances.utterance: I don't think they're going to give him the wall. I think they're hanging tight and they're saying, you know what, we're not going to give it to him. Let him have to bend. He already gave the TPS and DACA protections. He already compromised his humanitarian aid in his proposal. So I think he's going to get to a point where he's going to have to say, look, there's a humanitarian crisis at the border. This is an emergency. You've got caravan. Latest caravan numbers upward of 12,000 people. Something has to be done. The plan I put forth will not only prevent backlog in the immigration but will put money towards more border security agents, more lawyers. It wasn't just about a wall. But I think he was concerned about these federal workers not getting paid, and you saw three bills introduced in the House - -

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: -- that were motivated toward getting -- even if the shutdown continued, to get these federal workers paid. And Democrats just don't want that because they want this drama of, like, Trump, you've got to cave otherwise all of this is on your back. And I think he knows that. I think he's going to be forced into declaring a national emergency. And then he's going to get challenged in court.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, that's what I was about to say to you. He gets challenge in court and, of course, there -- you have to say what's the difference between the last two years or the last 30 days and now there's an emergency. And it sounds like, you know, the Democrats would have a strong argument that --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: The problem is there's been an emergency. You're right. It's not new. It has national attention now because of these caravans, but it's been a national emergency for a long time. It's not getting better. The situation is getting worse. So, if somebody doesn't dig their heels in and do something about it now, when is it going to be a good time to address?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Nothing is going to happen -- I mean, Jedediah is totally right. Nothing is going to happen in the next two years to suddenly make the Democrats become more pragmatic in terms of negotiating with the president around this. So, I agree. I think he should give it his best shot. Try to get them to negotiate in the next three weeks. But if not, declare a national emergency, fight it out in the courts, and move on to something else if they can get anything done for the next two years.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to D.C.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to D.C. But seriously, we should all talk in the break about this so they don't spring it on us tomorrow. I'm not taking the train. I don't want to take the train.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'll tell you what. It will be a caravan. You be at the front of the caravan. A caravan --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a caravan I'm really against.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There you go. All right. Up next, the freshman congresswoman facing new scrutiny for her past efforts to win leniency for men accused of trying to join ISIS. Stay with us on The Five.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. Democratic freshman congresswoman Ilhan Omar engulfed in a new controversy, this time for past efforts to convince a judge to show leniency toward a group of Minnesota men accused of trying to join ISIS. Omar writing in 2016, quote, the best deterrent to fanaticism is a system of compassion. We must alter our attitude and approach if we truly want to affect change. We should refocus our efforts on inclusion and rehabilitation. This isn't the first time Omar's comments have been scrutinized. She also falsely smear the Covington high school students, accused the USA of staging a coup in Venezuela, and deleted an offensive tweet about Israel. All right, Jesse, so I'm trying to figure out what it takes to be able to say that she's radical. I mean, this is crazy what she's saying. These are people who admittedly said that they were going to go to Syria. One guy went on record and said I was not going there to pass out medical kits or food. I was going to fight and kill on behalf of the Islamic State. And she's out there fighting --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Give him a chance.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Really? So -- I mean, this is not crazy what she's saying?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. If Minnesota wants to send radical kooks to Congress, that's their right. I mean, we've had terrible people in Congress. We've had addicts. We've had abusers. We've had molesters. We've had felons. This woman, though, is like a legitimate code pink activist, OK? She's saying we need to fight terrorism with compassion, sympathy, and inclusion. Is she on the House intel committee because that would be really scary. I think Pelosi has a huge problem on her hands. They're going to run ads all against her next year. And she's already -- I think what she said that Lindsey Graham was being sexually blackmail.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She said horrible things about Israel. She's a problem, but she's not my problem.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Why don't you have, though, Juan, Democrats in the party that still have their sanity that want to be able to appeal the independent voters, that want to be able to appeal to normal people who recognize that compassion toward people who are actively wanting to support ISIS is a bad idea. Why aren't they're out there saying -- holding her accountable and saying this is not reflective of the party?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second. Wait a second. Sounds to me like you guys have never heard of Steve King, or Louie Gohmert, or any of these guys on the right who I think, boy --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do they support ISIS?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is not supporting ISIS. She's not supporting ISIS in any way. And by the way --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: She has to decrease the amount of time that people who are going to fight with ISIS --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is a very important conversation. And she's making an important contribution to it by saying if you really want to deal with fanatics you have to understand how they think. And she's saying these people felt that they were not being included, that they could not be part of the system. She said we need restorative justice. You need to reach out to these people because you don't want more of them to come. We've all, right here on this sets said a lot of this ideology is like a cancer. It metastasizes and spreads. And you can't stop it just by use of violence or death penalties --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, you can. You sure can. Trump just did it. What is restorative justice?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Restorative justice is saying here is how you can become part of the community. Here's how you can make a contribution. Your life is valuable. You should not be involved in trying to kill people or kill yourself.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But here's the issue, though. If a group of people and their ideology dictates that everything about your culture is evil, I don't think any amount of restorative justice is going to work. You know, she's -- the thing that bugs me about this is two things. She's defending the worst kind of misogyny probably in modern history, responsible for thousands of gang rapes, sex slavery. So she's lost the moral authority to lecture anybody about Trump, OK?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: When did she defend gang rape?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Read up on ISIS. OK. So, here's the thing --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: In other words, it's not her.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No. Read up on ISIS.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She's defending people that were supporting gang rape and sexual slavery. So how do we not know about her beliefs beforehand? We were trained to stay away from honestly calling out her serious flaws because if you did, you would have been labeled misogynist and Islamophobic. So when she rose to the ranks and won, everybody had to do the golf clap. Oh, this is great. This is so progressive. How wonderful. But we don't learn about her troubling beliefs. She was aided and abetted by a compliant media who protected her. And we -- I'm not going to say anything bad about her. Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yeah. You know, Morgan, she's been elevate -- I mean, she's got like a $100 to $250,000 book deal now. This is not somebody --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How much did you say that was?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Support ISIS.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: There you go. That will be your ticket. No, but it's not only that they hadn't called her out but they have elevated her. I mean, you see her on TV all the time, getting a platform to talk about her beliefs, and nobody seems to be --

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Women's magazine.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Right. And nobody seems to be paying attention to what she's actually saying. I mean, is this woman going to be -- is she also going to decide she wants to run for president?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: The Democrat Party has a very serious problem with anti-Semitism that I think is festering and that they're not addressing. Her tweets about Israel, you could look them up. What she said about Venezuela, you know, last week, talking about that it was a coup from the U.S. She took the side of the Chinese and the Russians. I mean, these are things that she is saying that is just basic research that her staff could do. And first of all, let me say, there is a candidate, a Muslim candidate named Omar Qudrat, who was the first Republican to win a congressional primary, supported mainly by people of the Jewish faith in the Republican Party, who gave a ton of money to him. So there are people on the Republican side who are running for this, but she's the one who's been elevated, as you said, and been given this big platform. And until Democrats start to realize -- look, just tonight, while we're on here, there's a -- there's a bill that's going through the Senate that Marco Rubio has been pushing that is a bit that is anti-BDS, which is the sanctions against Israel. Schumer was able to get rid of the vote because he said, "Well, it's during the shutdown." All of these senators are going to start to be put on record, and they are afraid of the base, which is now becoming increasingly anti-Israel, increasingly hostile. And I think that there is simmering anti-Semitism in the base of the Democrat Party that they need to address.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think that's wishful thinking. I don't think Democrats -- and let me say, most Jews in the country are Democrats. There's not --

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Well, not this one.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We have -- we have a problem in the Democratic Party that was evident in terms of that Women's March that absolutely was a problem. But I'm just telling you this woman was elected in the state of Minnesota, has a track record in Minnesota, and those voters selected her. And that's why you're seeing her --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: But she also -- she also has a track record of saying grossly incorrect, horrible things. And then she deletes tweets and has to walk them back.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You should -- you should meet the rest of Congress.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I mean, these comments that she made about Covington High School, that was outrageous. She smeared an entire group of kids with doing absolutely no research. So I think the Democrats need to pay a little bit more attention to what she's been doing. But moving on, the first lady scores of big win after a fake news smear. See it, coming up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Fake news!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not going to D.C.! All right, the British paper The Daily Telegraph issued a humiliating apology on Saturday, admitting an article titled "The Mystery of Melania" was full of fake news about the first lady. They took it back and paid her substantial damages. There's no point in recounting the story's lies. They're the same stuff you heard many times before, part of a larger industry built on unknown sources and bitter bias. And it shows you the kind of year the media is having, and it's only been three weeks. But you have the Buzzfeed debacle, the Covington smear, layoffs at clickbait mills like Buzzfeed and "Huffington Post." CNN mocked for pretending they stumbled onto Roger Stone's arrest. And now you've got this brutal Telegraph humbling.

utterances.speaker: These events have one thing in common
utterances.utterance: accountability. It's new, and it's good for everyone, especially you, because you may not know how false the Melania coverage is, but you can bet she does. And that's the point. You never know what fake news is until it's about you.

utterances.speaker: Ask anyone who's ever been the subject of a story. Unless they're vacuous actors pumping a socially conscious film, it's never, ever good. It's why, love him or hate him, Trump's war with fake news makes the past two years' worth it. His disruption has exposed the hidden levers in so many dark guards
utterances.utterance: from trade to immigration to copy editing and fact-checking. So if only one result from the Trump era is that -- is the media thinks that twice before destroying someone for fun and profit, then I'd call that a win. Wouldn't you? All right. Every single person here has been the subject of a story. How close was the story to the facts?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Oh, I mean, I was the subject of several but when I left a particular show, I remember seeing something in The Daily Mail and reading it and being like, "False, false."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I would say 80 percent of it was false.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: And they put just enough truth in there, where there's, like, a tiny nugget of truth and they count on you not doing anything. I didn't do anything about it, because I was advised, "Leave it."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: "You're going to add fuel to the fire. You're going to draw attention to it." But the truth is, then you let it sit out there, and it drives you crazy, because you're like, "This is not me. This is a false perception. And if anybody reads it, you don't want them to walk away thinking that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Its forever.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: And it's forever.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It sits out there.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: It's infuriating.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It sits out there, but to her -- to Jed's point, Jesse, if you like -- it's why Trump is refreshing, in that he actually is willing to go chase this thing like a dog and catch the car.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. It's -- this is like Wikipedia is more accurate that some of this stuff. And they got basic facts wrong. I think Americans need to realize something, Greg. Journalists are not that bright. These people, they didn't graduate first in their class from Harvard. They live in small apartments in New York and D.C. They don't have a lot of money.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So do most of us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They're boring people at parties. They -- if you line them up between bankers and advertising executives and lawyers, they rank dead last on intelligence. Think about it. They get stuff wrong all the time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You are the king of generalizations.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's true. I mean, they called the White House Correspondents' Dinner party "nerd prom" --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- because it's filled with nerds. These people aren't that intelligent, but they act superior; and they hate Donald Trump. And they're riddled with errors in their stories. And guess what? All of the errors make Republicans look bad. Why is it that they never make mistakes that make Democrats look bad? It's always on the other side.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: They make mistakes that make them look good. They make stuff up to make them look good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, Juan, you -- when I asked -- in the break, I said, "Have you been the subject of a story? And how close was it to the truth?" And you were like "Ha!" So it's happened to you, and you are a journalist. It's happened to you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. And by the way, I don't know about the small apartment. I better inform my wife and a bunch of people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You've done well for yourself, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But -- but I must say that, to me, you know, when you see what happened with The Daily Telegraph, they have to pay, apparently, some million -- more than a million dollars, right, plus her legal fees. So they were wrong. But I must say, a lot of this comes from "Fire and Fury."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A lot of this comes -- I think there are now several books. I think there's a book out this week about Trump. A lot of this doesn't seem, Jesse, like it's myths. A lot of it comes from inside the Trump camp by people who worked with him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They had basic facts wrong.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No they did --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They had dates and time lines --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There's a bigger story here about this president. That you're saying, oh -- to the audience, "Oh, just ignore everything that's negative about Trump, because these guys got it wrong."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's the problem, is because the media gets so many things wrong about Republicans.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, come on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: When they do get something right and it's real news, no one believes them when they're right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'll tell you --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They have no track record.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You want to go back and see how much attention Donald Trump got from the CNNs and MSNBCs of the world that put him on the air?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Just because he got attention doesn't make it accurate.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me say, when he goes after Buzzfeed, right, for their problems or Huff Post or goes after The New York Post, because they're laying off people, I think, man, that is low. So in other words, you're going to hit journalists who are being fired.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Those same journalists love getting people fired.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They want you fired, Juan. They want me fired.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They revel in it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan, The Huffington Post has rarely --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They're not clean.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What The Huffington Post does is they repurpose articles that were done -- either Media Matters will put out something. Then Mediaite picks it up. And then Huffington Post repurposes it all, with the purpose of screwing over people who are generally to the right of them, and getting them fired. So I have no sympathy. And I wrote -- remember, I wrote for The Huffington Post for ten years, I think. I tend to forget that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It was a long time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It was a long time. So here's -- here's the bigger thing, Morgan. It used to be rare that Joe Blow would be a target of the media. But now we're in this area where anyone tangentially related to Trump, voting for Trump --

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- supporting Trump, wearing a red hat at the Washington Monument --

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- no one is safe. So I think it's important now that we really go to war.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I think it's important that you bring that up, because you know, in the whole Covington thing, I almost tweeted -- just by watching the video, I almost tweeted and said, "What are these kids doing?"

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I did. I made a mistake.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I stopped. I stopped, and I'm glad I did. And I waited a day and looked at the news. And then you say, "Wait a minute. There's a fuller story here." But if you talk more about media accountability writ large, Juan is right, actually. In the Republican primary, it was estimated in the general election, in the 2016 campaign, that Trump got probably, what two billion dollars' worth of free media. So I think what is happening now is, even though they won't admit it out loud --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Guilt.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I do. I think it's guilt that they realize that they let him call into these TV shows on a daily basis. They showed all of his -- every network showed all of the rallies live. They did all of these things. And now, I think that these other networks and journalistic outfits feel a little bit of culpability, and so they have overextended. And of course, you know, it's all ratings.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, they're -- yes.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Andrew Breitbart was talking about the war with the media before it was cool. Because everybody else was talking about elections and politicians. And he was out there saying the problem is the media. That's where your fight is. And he was 100 percent right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. We're not done yet. Harry Potter -- who's that? It's a guy in my garden -- taking a shot at Patriots quarterback Tom Brady but for a surprise reason. That's next.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: The New England Patriots and their star quarterback, Tom Brady, are no stranger to criticism and being rooted against. But this time it's coming from a little bit of an unusual place. Actor Daniel Radcliffe. Who's that again? Well, he played harry Potter, and he is taking a swipe at Brady while promoting a new movie.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Who are you rooting for in the Super Bowl?

utterances.speaker: DANIEL RADCLIFFE, ACTOR
utterances.utterance: Rams.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: RADCLIFFE
utterances.utterance: Because, like, the whole world is rooting against the Patriots. Sorry.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Should Tom Brady retire?

utterances.speaker: RADCLIFFE
utterances.utterance: No. But, like, he should just stop winning things. Take that MAGA hat out of your locker. I feel that that was a moment when, as a country, we were all like, "Come on, dude. We want to be "You're awesome' and behind you. Don't put that in there."

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: The hat in question is a 2015 gift that President Trump gave to Patriots owner Robert Kraft to hand off to Brady. Greg, I feel like everyone should be rooting against Brady because he's a cheater, not because of the MAGA hat. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Ooh, wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Being as though we both went to Serra High School, I'm going to let that slide. Two observations here. The problem with British celebrities is the bigness of the United States. So whenever they look at the United States, they have an insecurity complex. He looks over. What did he say? He wished Brady would stop winning things. That's very British celebrity, because they prefer to be very small. But back to the -- back to almost what I said yesterday. The smear is widening. So it's not about Trump or Republicans. It's anyone who has an affiliation or sympathy. We have a cultural witch hunt going on. "You have that hat on the locker? I can't be your friend."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Witch hunt?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Witch hunt.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Where did you get that phrase?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know! Warlock hunt.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, there you go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go. Although that sounds gross, but anyway.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Juan, do you think that malpeople shouldn't be friends with people who wear MAGA hats? Is it a racist hat?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: To me, look, I mean, you've got to just be open-minded about it and say, OK. But I must say I don't understand that you don't -- you guys don't see that this hat is loaded with meaning for people in terms of being associated with Donald Trump --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What about a Malcolm X hat?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- from the very -- yes, if you want to say that, fine. But we know what Malcolm X stood for.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And we know what Donald Trump stands for. And if it's grabbing women --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Are you saying they're the same?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, definitely not. And if it's grabbing women or talking about Mexicans as rapists and thieves.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Or job growth.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: If it's anti- -- no one's job growth. Wear an Obama hat in that case.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The biggest history, and minorities, women and the job history.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm just saying there's -- I mean, and the racism, the misogyny. I think a lot of people think, "What are you doing with this hat? You don't understand what you are --"

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So you are smearing everybody wearing the hat?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: So Jedediah, I mean, I root for the Eagles, but other than that, I choose my quarterbacks based off who's the cutest. Like, that's how I decide who I want to root for, which is very Sporty Spice of me. What do you think about this? Can we even have a Super Bowl without people getting political? Or do you think --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: -- Super Bowl parties, it's going to be --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: -- MAGA hat versus Obama hat?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You can't, because it drives -- for some reason liberals are uncomfortable, like, with the fact that somebody disagrees. I don't know why it bothers him that somebody has a MAGA hat. Like, who cares? It's not your hat. You don't have to wear it. It didn't drive me crazy to walk around New York City and see --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dresses like a little sorcerer --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: -- a million Obama hats. And it's because that liberal mentality, though, is a collectivist mentality. And I think a lot of times they are rubbed the wrong way. Not all, but many are rubbed the wrong way by somebody who disagrees, who doesn't see the world the same way. They can't quite understand that. And I think we're in a world now where everything is political. You can't -- we saw with the NFL. It became super political. But people are tired, because when it became super political, people started, you know, turning the channel. And then they were brought back in when that political component was back out of it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So you going to change the channel on Mookie Betts, who says he's not going to the White House with the Sox? Are you going to change the channel on the NBA team, LeBron James.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: There has to be a space where it's not political, though, and it's not --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because -- we don't -- we separate the political and personal. Political is not personal for me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: For me, like, I'm a huge Will Ferrell fan, right? And he hates Republicans.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He probably hates you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All -- he hates me. Yes, I put all of my Will Ferrell clips in the "Watters' World" package.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I was able to separate. See how that's done, Juan? You separate. My mom loves me, roots for me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I have a MAGA hat. She separates.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Separate.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Separate.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think Tom Brady's wife was very clear in saying, "We do not back Trump." And she was trying to get the political out.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Did she say that? I think she told him not to talk politics.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Then I'll go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And she said, "We didn't back him."

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: And she said that. She did say that.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: OK. Well, there you go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is a new one.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: So before we go -- who is Daniel Radcliffe again? OK, before we go, we have some big news. President Trump has accepted Nancy Pelosi's invitation, and Greg is going to have to go to D.C.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No!

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: To deliver the State of the Union next Tuesday. "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That is not happening.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's time now for "One More Thing." I have some workout tips.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Oh, boy.

utterances.speaker: Graphic
utterances.utterance: "Jesse's Workout Tips."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: "Jesse's Workout Tips." Wow. Yes, that's real. What were those, 70 pounds? I'm just warming up with those buddies. So work out at the gym. Do not work out at the office, all right? Have you seen these exercise balls? Roll this tape, please. You know, people sit on them at their desk desk.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I love -- you have to keep these here at all times.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. She tried to do a little, you know -- see how it works. It doesn't work well. People are falling off these things all over at FOX News. They're unsafe, and I don't like them. So let's get rid of them. Work out at the gym, not at the office. All right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Lawsuit. I smell a lawsuit.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Against me?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I apologize. Go ahead, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Time for --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD (singing)
utterances.utterance: Animals are great! Animals are great! Animals are great!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know, guys. I'm killing you with it. I'm slowly destroying your brain. You know, porcupines, they love bananas. Baby porcupines love bananas even more.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Oh, no!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Check out this baby porcupines eating a banana. I don't think I've ever seen somebody or something love a banana more than this baby porcupine. Look at that giant nose that porcupine has. And look at the way he just eats that. You know, when I watch a porcupine eat a banana all I can say to myself is --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD (singing)
utterances.utterance: Animals are great! Animals are great! Animals are great!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was a pretty good one. All right. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, you know, there's frigid weather heading this way in New York, New England, the middle Atlantic states, but especially in the Midwest. And right now off the coast of Dana Point in southern California the temperatures are closer to summertime, and there's a very special rainbow there to warm your heart. Take a look.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is that a --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's a humpback whale and her calf, and they're blowing rainbows. A drone recorded this colorful show Saturday, the whales are migrating from Central America to Dana Point to feed on the bridge. By the way, whale touring companies in that area say they have seen 42 humpbacks so far this January, compared to only four a year ago.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Blowing rainbows.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, so --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That sounds like a euphemism.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So as your teeth are chattering over the next few days, remember the warmth and beauty of this scene off Dana Point.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Ohh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So cute.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Jedediah. I'm not going to make a joke. It's just too wholesome.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Well, I have some good news. Cassie, a mixed breed, a 5-year-old mixed breed, has found her forever home. Happy puppy in Ohio. The Humane Society of Dayton shared the news on Facebook. Cassie gained popularity after making an appearance in a commercial for a car dealership, posing as a super good girl on local TV stations. And her new owner saw the commercial, was drawn to her. So she has been adopted into her forever home and I believe she has been adopted before it brought back, which made me very sad. So I am so happy that she has found a forever home.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Forever homes.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yay.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: It's fate. So my "One More Thing" is about something that could only happen to men in a road rage accident. There's shocking video, if you haven't seen this today, coming out of Massachusetts. Watch this as this man climbs on the hood of a speeding SUV down the highway. Richard Kamaraski (ph), 65-year-old man, and 37-year-old Mark Fitzgerald, they got in a car accident on the turnpike. Fitzgerald tried to leave the scene. This guy jumps on the hood of the car. I mean, it's a hot mess. He stayed on there for two or 3 miles.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Two or three miles?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Sometimes the -- and the driver got up to 70 miles an hour. This is why I said this would only happen to men. Women would not do this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Second sexist thing you've said today. You are a sexist.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Luckily two motorists helped bring the dangerous situation to an end by boxing the SUV in, and the rest is history.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Greg --

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
